description.narrative: The projects seeks to strengthen government capacities and create rosters for national and international experts in different development fields, as well as undertake pilot assessments and develop strategic response plans.

title.narrative: CSI CDR by Project from Jan-March 2013
CSI Procurment and Recruitment Plan for 2013
CSI Signed CDR from January to June 2013
International Consultant ? Lead Facilitator and Team Building Practitioner
International Consultants (02) ? Experts on Policy Formulation and Government Planning (trainer)

description.narrative: Capacity Strengthening Initiative by conducting government needs assessment and providing them with a roster of national and international experts in different development affairs.
capital of a political entity
Accountability - local government finance

Indicators: - Number of areas of intervention identified -Type of capacity needs identified and type of support required - Country specific training resources developed and made available in Arabic -Baselines and targets are established for assessing - Nb of government officials trained -Type of sectors benefiting from specialized expertise -Type of studies/plans carried out -Nb of experts made available (days per year per sector per activity) Engagement of key stakeholder in the needs assessment exercise -Needs assessment of MoLCB, selected local councils and MoI implemented -Strategic response strategic developed -Strategic response integrated in national plans for capacity building -Engagement of women in the assessment process

comment.narrative: Baseline: -Weak technical capacity and knowledge of international best practices in specific units/ areas pertaining to government work -Weak organizational structures and job descriptions -Absence of structured inter-ministerial coordination -Weak capacity of government officials in specific technical and management areas necessary for the government machinery -Weak capacity to identify immediate technical expertise in a timely manner -Lack of government data on experts at the international, regional and local level -Weak institutional connection with the Libyan Diaspora -Weak institutional capacities at key ministries -Capacities of institutions in sync with their new mandates after the revolution -Capacities of institutions unable to respond to urgent planning at the national level

1. Type of capacity needs identified and type of support required 2. Number of government officials trained 3. Type of sectors benefiting from specialized expertise 4. Nb of experts made available (days per year per sector per activity)

The support provided by UNDP by deploying embedded technical experts at the ministry of planning increased the efficiency of the ministry in dealing with international community with regard to assistance to Libya. Moreover, the UNDP support to Line ministries related to Government Programme Planning and policy formulation process enhanced the skills of government staff.

1. Type of capacity needs identified and type of support required 2. Number of government officials trained 3. Type of sectors benefiting from specialized expertise 4. Nb of experts made available (days per year per sector per activity)

title.narrative: Support to Civic Engagement in Libyas Transition SCELT

description.narrative: In partnership with Ministries of Planning, Culture & Civil Society, Higher Education and Al Awqaf, the project facilitates greater engagement of Libyan citizens to engage actively in the transition to democracy

title.narrative: International Consultant ? Civic Education for Women & Girls for the CEGF Preparatory Workshop

description.narrative: Support to Civic Engagement by including active citizen participation initiatives and awareness raising to facilitate the democratic transition of the nation, with the Ministries of Planning, Culture & Civil Society and Higher Education.
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

Indicators: - NGO law imitated drafted and submitted. - consultation dialogue with NGO concerning the drafted law undertaken - international relevant experience exposed - Nb of students benefiting directly from civic education classes and/or model democratic processes - Nb of reference materials produced for teachers and students - Nb of edutainment products - Nb of monitoring initiatives led by youth - Nb of monitoring reports on youth issues & transition disseminated to decision-makers - Advocacy by civil society on enhancing the role of women in transition - Nb of professional Libyan facilitators - Number of CSOs receiving sub-grants and implementing activities - Number of CSOs receiving financial management and implementation mentoring and support - Increase in capacity [May 2016 ] among targeted CSOs compared to baseline capacity assessment [October 2015] - Web Portal on-line, accessible, up-to-date and used by up to 50 CSOs - Web & App Designer agreement signed - Format for Web Portal & Mobile App designed - Number of CSOs using Beta version of web portal/app [disaggregated according to female and male-lead organisations with minimum 50% female] - Number of CSOs using Web portal/App in first week following Launch [disaggregated according to female and male-lead organisation with minimum 50% female]

comment.narrative:
Baseline: - Libyan NGO legislation does not protect freedom of expression and association ; only adhoc measures have been taken post-revolution to facilitate NGO registration - Absence of evidence-based knowledge of civic education needs - No coordination and information-sharing
- Knowledge of democracy & good governance among the youth in Libya is limited, but desire to engage actively in the transition is very high - Total student population is 250,000. - Lack of reference materials and outreach products on civic education adapted to the youth - No independent monitoring of the transition done according to credible indicator framework - Youth issues not sufficiently mainstreaming into public policies
- No government strategy to improve the role of women in building peace and democracy in Libya. - Nascent womens rights movement in Libya. - Women are traditionally kept out of the political sphere.
- Lack of qualified dialogue facilitators in Libya and limited training opportunities - No framework for national dialogue and lack of dialogue culture - Certain population groups with little access to dialogue opportunities.

Civic Engagement Grant Fund Phase 3: Twelve sub-grants are provided to CS organisations to implement Output 2-4 activities over a 4 month period Twelve key CS organizations will be targeted with capacity development and mentoring in proposal development, financial management and the implementation of activities supported through sub-grants A national Web Portal/Mobile on Civil Society in Libya will be designed and managed and updated monthly Training: Libyan CSO capacity for civic education and engagement will be developed through the Civic Engagement Grant Fund through targeted training based on capacity assessment for 32 CSOs CSO implemented activities under Grant Fund in 1- Women & girls civic education and engagement, 2- Youth leadership & engagement, 3- Conflict analysis and dialogue facilitation 4- Promoting dialogue and responsiveness & accountability of Municipalities to citizen engagement in supporting effective services; Development of CSO Toolkits in: - Women & Girls Civic education - Youth Engagement & Leadership - Conflict Analysis and Dialogue - Civic engagement with Municipalities

Through the 13 projects implemented, there was a wide range of workshops and awareness-raising activities implemented, regions covered, and target groups reached (directly and indirectly). A total of approximately 209 activities were implemented under the 13 grant fund projects. In total, 100 workshops, 31 discussion sessions / dialogue debate sessions and 11 media & awareness raising campaigns, 22 field visits were conducted and 34 videos were produced, reaching approximately more than 1,821 direct beneficiaries (approximately 45% women and 55% men) and more than 30,775 indirect beneficiaries in the South, East, Middle, and West regions of the country. These numbers are approximate as in some cases the CSOs did not report numbers of beneficiaries desegregated by gender, and others did not report on indirect beneficiaries although their outreach did extend beyond the direct beneficiaries that participated in the activities A national Web Portal/Mobile on Civil Society in Libya had developed with almost 200 Libyan CSO`s registered. (NGOS.ly) CSO Toolkit in; - Women & Girls Civic education, - Youth Engagement & Leadership, - Conflict Analysis and Dialogue, - Civic engagement with Municipalities had developed and handed over to the 12 CSO`s granted for CEGF phase III. On the regional and south to south corporation level the project had funded: 1- Three Libyan CSO`s representatives to attend Arab Regional Conference on the Role of Civil Society in Implementing Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development scheduled on 20-21 April 2016 in Doha, (Qatar). 2- Two Libyan youth activists to attended Youth, Peace, and Security in the Arab States Region: A Consultation and High-level Dialogue 4 6 December 2016 Amman (Jordan)

Civic Engagement Grant Fund Phase 3: Twelve sub-grants are provided to CS organisations to implement Output 2-4 activities over a 4 month period Twelve key CS organizations will be targeted with capacity development and mentoring in proposal development, financial management and the implementation of activities supported through sub-grants A national Web Portal/Mobile on Civil Society in Libya will be designed and managed and updated monthly Training: Libyan CSO capacity for civic education and engagement will be developed through the Civic Engagement Grant Fund through targeted training based on capacity assessment for 32 CSOs CSO implemented activities under Grant Fund in 1- Women & girls civic education and engagement, 2- Youth leadership & engagement, 3- Conflict analysis and dialogue facilitation 4- Promoting dialogue and responsiveness & accountability of Municipalities to citizen engagement in supporting effective services; Development of CSO Toolkits in: - Women & Girls Civic education - Youth Engagement & Leadership - Conflict Analysis and Dialogue - Civic engagement with Municipalities

description.narrative: the project supports the government to prepare for well -administered, transparent and credible elections that represent the will of the Libyan people and meet international best practices.

title.narrative: To evaluate the impacts of LEAP project during the period 2012-2015
Gender Legal Consultant for Libya Electoral Assistance Project (LEAP)
International Consultant ? Facilitator - Training of Trainers (ToT) Workshop
International Consultant ? Lead Facilitator for Electoral Budgeting Workshop
Public Opinion Survey ?National Survey of Libya ? Electoral participation?

description.narrative: core activities with HNEC such as civic and voter education, support to electoral dispute resolution, assistance with planning electoral security, support with out-of-country voting, and procurement.
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

(1) Transitional authorities manage fair and inclusive democratic processes (Source: CPD 2012-15) (2) Transparent, credible elections; results accepted by the Libyan electorate (Source LEAP M&E Framework, 2013) (3) Electoral institutions and practices adhering to international good practices enshrined in emerging national legal framework (Source: LEAP M&E Framework, 2013)

comment.narrative: (1) National congress replaces NTC and launches democratic processes in 2012 (Source: CPD 2012-15) (2) No national elections held in Libya since 1965 (Source: LEAP 2012 Project Document) (3) Electoral management body sworn in on 12 February 2012; new body has minimal capacity (Source: LEAP 2012 Project Document)

1) HNEC's organisational, management, and technical capacities to plan, prepare and manage successive credible and transparent elections are strengthened. 2) awareness and knowledge of critical electoral issues strengthened.

1) Finalizing an electoral gender mapping document 2) supporting the HNEC with voter registration software training 3) working closely with IFES with HNEC senior management on designing a plan for voter education and public outreach strategy for potential referendum event

1) HNEC's organisational, management, and technical capacities to plan, prepare and manage successive credible and transparent elections are strengthened. 2) awareness and knowledge of critical electoral issues strengthened.

1) supporting the HNEC with voter registration software training 2) working closely with IFES with HNEC senior management on designing a plan for voter education and public outreach strategy for potential referendum event.
As per the external evaluation, the overall conclusion on the UNDPs election assistance project is that it was generally successful, in that it assisted the HNEC and other Libyan stakeholders in organizing three well-regarded elections in a fairly short time, in a country which did not at all have a history of electoral democracy.

title.narrative: Support to Transitional Governance Structures in Libya

description.narrative: the project provides targeted technical support to assist the Government to build the capacity of transitional governance structures. Priorities are: the decentralization, rule of law programs and elections and constitution formulation

description.narrative: Targeted technical support to assist the Government of Libya to build the capacity of transitional governance structures.
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption

comment.narrative: Local Government - Local governments have limited capacity for development planning, budgeting and implementation; lack of dependable data/ statistics on demography and service users Parliamentary Support - No recent history of an elected parliament and its role in a democratic society - Little understanding of parliamentary functions of roles by elected MPs - Limited consultative engagement between parliament and citizens - No recent history of parliamentary groups Constitution - Elections were held in July 2012 but no constitution yet in place. Elections for the Constitution Drafting Assembly are expected to take place in December 2013. According to the Constitutional Declaration a constitutional referendum is currently foreseen for 2014. The GNC was put in place in August 2013 but there is limited parliamentary experience. Rule of Law & Human Rights: Lack of clear procedures which contribute to slowness in processing cases; lack of access to legal materials by judges and staff; publics lack of awareness of their legal rights and legal procedures; inadequate information available for public awareness of legal rights; women face difficulties in access to justice; no system to ensure sustainability of reforms

1.The CDA has been provided with the means to implement public consultation and outreach process for receiving public consultations. 2.The CDA provided with assistance in media and communication. 3.Libyan population receive informed messages on the constitution making process and substance. 4.Libyan academia and other key stakeholders have been engaged in the constitution-making process through the production of papers, organization of public debates and workshops. Libyan population engaged in the constitution-making through participation in targeted survey. 5.Enhanced coordination between Libyan and international actors in the constitution-making process. 6.CSOs/NGOs are equipped with the necessary tools, instruments and capacity to effectively engage media and outreach campaign.
The CDA provided with the means to implement public consultation and outreach process for receiving public consultation.

1.The CDA provided with assistance in media and communication. 2.Libyan population receive informed messages on the constitution making process and substance. 3.Libyan academia and other key stakeholders have been engaged in the constitution-making process through the production of papers, organization of public debates and workshops. Libyan population engaged in the constitution-making through participation in targeted survey.
results to be updated at the beginning of 2018

description.narrative: The dialogue seeks to discuss steps to advance a transitional justice process that includes reparations and the safe and dignified return of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs).

participating-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

provider-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.
US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.
US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: 1- Inclusiveness of dialogue process. 2- Incorporation of women's demands into draft political agreement. 3 - Safe and neutral platform provided for dialogue. 4- GNA national programme priorities defined. 5- Number of national priorities for GNA identified for project support with policy strategy and implementation plan. 6- Capacity strengthened in supported institutions.

comment.narrative: 1- Major Libyan political actors involved in various dialogue meetings. 2- No women's demands included in the draft political agreement. 3- Willingness exists amongst participants to meet 4- No national priorities for GNA defined. 5- No national priorities for GNA defined. 6-Supported institutions not defined and no capacity assessment undertaken.

1. Main political dialogue process towards implementation supported 2. Incorporation of women's demands into draft political agreement 3. Safe and neutral platform for inter-tribal political dialogue provided 4. Dialogues towards improved security supported 5. National priorities for GNA identified for project support in selected institutions identified 6. Core government functions re-established

1-The project most recently supported a major political dialogue in Malta in November 2016 which called on the HoR to amend the Constitutional Declaration to incorporate the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA), and on the PC to address the dismal security, social and economic problems facing the people of Libya
2-The project has supported the inclusion of the establishment of a women support unit in the LPA. The projects support to the LPA implementation has further contributed to the formalized establishment of the unit
3-The project has supported cross-community reconciliation between Misrata and Tawergha, which have resulted in a breakthrough signing of an agreement on 30 August 2016 stipulating the return of the displaced and compensation of those affected.
4-The UNDP political dialogue project has supported UNSMIL to assist the Presidency Council (PC) appoint a Temporary Security Committee (TSC), as outlined in the LPA. The TSC meeting facilitated by the project/UNSMIL enabled the PC and the TSC to agree on a Tripoli security plan, and the establishment of a Presidential Guard
5-The project is assisting GNA re-establish core government functions by strengthen the overall technical administrative competency and skills of its staff. To this effect the project has initiated the recruitment of international and Libyan experts to build the capacity of the Libyan public administration
6-The project is assisting the GNA to re-establish core government functions in order to generate evidence based, factually strong policy recommendations to assist GNA reform and rebuild the public sector art large. The first assessment on Government Employees / Civil Service Reform has been completed, while three others are underway.

1. Main political dialogue process towards implementation supported 2. Incorporation of women's demands into draft political agreement 3. Safe and neutral platform for inter-tribal political dialogue provided 4. Dialogues towards improved security supported 5. National priorities for GNA identified for project support in selected institutions identified 6. Core government functions re-established

Dialogue between the Misrata and Tawergha communities resulted in an agreement to negotiate on implementing the right to voluntary return of the Tawerghans to Misrata. A Joint Committee with representatives from both groups agreed to a roadmap. Aan agreement was signed addressing the return of the displaced, and compensation for those affected. The roadmap for reparations, voluntary return of internally displaced persons and framework for reparations represents significant progress towards transitional justice.

description.narrative:
O. 1 - Number of municipal needs assessments conducted - Number of light infrastructure rehabilitated - Number of equipment provided - Number of critical businesses rehabilitated
O. 2 - Number of capacity assessments - Number of technical experts deployed - Number of local authorities with increased capacity O. 3 - Number of local assessments conducted - Number of civic engagement campaigns - Number of youth and women engaged - Number of municipalities trained and engaged in conflict resolution efforts

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Light infrastructure destroyed by conflict rehabilitated and recovery of critical businesses supported Key infrastructure destroyed in the intensified conflict since mid-2014 disrupting the regular functioning of hospitals, schools, roads, electricity networks, power grids, police stations, and water facilities - Local businesses (MSMEs) impacted by the crisis. - Lack of viable economic opportunities for jobs and income generation for youth, including vulnerable groups (IDPs, returnees, and migrants).
Output 2: Immediate capacity boost to municipalities provided - Municipalities lack human resource and financial capacity to effective function in their role as local authorities. - Traditional and weak bureaucratic systems in local institutions (municipalities and executive bodies) - Current partnership building between local actors is ad hoc, externally driven, unstructured and reactive. - Inadequate levels of financial transparency. - Limited engagement with civil society and media. - Marked decrease in access to and quality of basic services in certain areas and even more so for the 700,000 persons of concern (IDPs, refugees, migrants).
Output 3: Local conflict analysis, facilitation and mediation capacity strengthened - Role of municipalities in mediation and conflict resolution remains ad hoc. - Traditional leaders and structures play an important role in local mediation and conflict mitigation, but these efforts mainly act as mitigation of escalation following an incident, rather than as an effective peacebuilding mechanism. - Existing conflict management and dialogue efforts at local level are not sufficiently visible, remain ad hoc and reactive rather than preventative. - Level of violent criminality and threats against private property increasing across the country. - Protective system for women against violence is weak, due to institutional and cultural barriers.

O. 1 Rapid needs assessment carried out in all municipalities where the project will be implemented 100% of agreed light infrastructure works completed in the selected municipalities (the exact number and nature of the works will be defined by the needs assessment) 100% of agreed MSMEs rehabilitated and 100% of the agreed equipment provided (the exact number and nature of the MSMEs and required equipment will be defined by the needs assessment)
O. 2 Capacity gaps assessed in all municipalities where the programme is being implemented. Based on the agreed requirements, technical experts deployed in selected municipalities to build capacity. Municipal strategic plans developed in all agreed locations
O. 3 Strategic partnerships with four NGOs working in Libya initiated. Localized conflict analysis completed in areas identified by the board. Capacity of municipal and local leaders on conflict resolution enhanced At least two civic engagement campaigns led by youth organizations.

O. 1 - Needs assessment conducted in 3 municipalities (Benghazi, Kikla and Obari) - Initial assessment on conflict dynamics conducted in Sirte municipality - 22 civil works to rehabilitate damaged infrastructure identified as priority (15 brought to tender) - 30 equipment needs identified and prioritized (17 brought to tender) - 11 regular ambulances & 11 ICU ambulances delivered to support access to health services in three municipalities - 8 garbage trucks delivered to enhance public health in 3 municipalities
O. 2 - Delivery Advisor hired and providing technical assistance to Ministry of Plan - Recruitment of Municipal Liaison Office finalized; will begin 1 January 2017 - Communications training implemented in December (2 specialists from each project site: Benghazi, Kikla, and Obari plus 2 from Presidential Council, PC)
O. 3 - Perception survey initiated on view of citizens on service delivery of the GNA and Municipalities - Consultations with Tribal Leaders from Benghazi, Kikla and Obari conducted to identify conflict mitigation measures needed and their monitoring - 3 municipalities engaged in conflict resolution efforts (social peace partnerships established in 2)

O. 1 1. Five assessments completed. 2. Benghazi: 60% (6/10) Kikla: 100% (4/4) Obari: 60% (4/7) Sebha: 20% (1/5) Sirte: 13% (3/23) TOTAL: 36% (18/49)
3. Benghazi: 55% (5/9) Kikla: 100% (14/14) Obari: 100% (5/5) Sebha: 15% (2/13) Sirte: 13% (3/23) TOTAL: 45% (29/64)
O.2 1. 4/5 municipalities underwent a capacity assessment. 2. 4/5 municipalities have a technical expert embedded in the municipal office. 3. 4/5 municipalities report their needs as substantially reduced
O.3 1.
2. Social Peace Partnerships in place and meeting at least quarterly. 3. Benghazi: 100; W:5; Y:10 Kikla: 100; W:5; Y:10 Obari: 200; W:5; Y:10 Sebha: 100; W:5; Y:10 Sirte: 100; W:5; Y:10 4. At least five conflicts addressed by peace structures in each community in 2018. 5. At least three municipalities where social peace structures report a decline in number of incidents.
on track report available in January 2018

title.narrative: Support to Misrata/Tawergha Joint Committee at the Local and National level

description.narrative: This project aims to assist the Misrata/Tawergha Joint Committee in implementing a reparation programme and facilitate the return of the Tawerghans, and people from al-Kararim, Tomina and Karzaz.

title.narrative: Rehabilitation of Psychosocial Support Center in Misrata, Libya
Support to Misrata/Tawergha Joint Committee at the local and national levels

description.narrative: This output seeks to enable the key parties to the disputes from displaced communities to continue the dialogue process on transitional justice and return of IDPs.
seat of a first-order administrative division
Health - policy, planning and administration

Output 1 a) Implementation plan for the roadmap developed for the Misrata/ Tawergha dialogue process (Y/N) b) % respondents at the community level indicating increase in levels of confidence in returning to their communities (M/F) c) # of communities that enter into dialogue processes
Output 2
a) Transitional justice strategies developed for the different dialogue processes, including action plan for reparations for Misrata/Tawergha b) Increased awareness of options for transitional justice mechanism at the national level c) # of conflict affected populations provided legal and psychosocial support for Misrata/Tawergha (M/F)
output 3
a) # of negotiated community security plans in target communities b) Perception of level of safety and security among the returning IDP population (age and gender disaggregated)

comment.narrative: output 1 a) Newly negotiated roadmap exists for Tawergha and Misrata b) No baselines exist assessing perceptions of IDP communities on confidence in returning to their communities c) Misrata and Tawergha have entered into a dialogue process output 2 a) Misrata/Tawergha Road Map b) No transitional justice mechanism exists at national or local level d) No assessment of the legal and psychosocial support needed for Misrata/Tawergha output 3 a) No community security plan in place b) Basic assessments on community security in targeted areas (perception survey)

1- a) Dialogue with Misrata and Twaergha continues and the Joint Committee agree on an implementation plan for the roadmap (Y1)
2 - Increase in level of confidence in IDPs returning to their communities
3- A transitional justice strategy is developed for all the dialogue processes, including on reparations, building on the Misrata/Tawergha Road Map and through a broad consultative process

Signing of the Misrata-Tawergha Agreement on the Return of the Displaced and Compensation of those Affected, 30 August 2016 provides for the: Establishment of a Joint Committee for Misrata and Tawergha The development of a Road Map agreement for reparations and return of IDPs Preparation of a framework for reparations for victims by the Joint Committee A plan to implement the right of IDPs from Tawergha to return to their city and the implementation of a reparations programme for victims. With the signature of the Road Map agreement the project helped mobilize support for UNDPs Transitional Justice project.

Output 1 1) A comprehensive data base of IDPs disaggregated by sex and IDP camps is established (Tawergha and Misrata). 2) The implementation of the roadmap and operational plan at the community level for the Misrata/Tawergha is continously supported
Output 2 1) The development of a transitional justice strategy / roadmap for the Mashasyah / Zinta conflict is supported. 2)The capacity of the judiciay at local level (Tawergha / Misrata) in reducing backlog of cases of detainees and missing persons is on strategic level strengthened. 3) A plan to establish psychosocial support center for the Tawergha and Misrata communities is devised and its implemenation supported
Output 3 A plan to increase the level of confidence of IDPS for returning of the targeted popolution of Tawergha and Misrata is developed.
on tract to be reported in early 2018

description.narrative: Output 1: Better provision of basic services at local level and access for most vulnerable groups. Output 2: Local authorities and administration supported in enforcing stability and security. Output 3: Local economic recovery supported.
seat of a first-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

a) number of evidence-based plans developed by municipalities and/or clusters of municipalities with participation of societal stakeholders. b) percentage of municipal staff in target locations noting greater professionalism and responsiveness in their institution. c) percentage of population (disaggregated by gender and by displacement status) in target locations noting improvement in the delivery of 3 key services. d) Frequency of use of gender- specific indicators in municipal policies and plans in target locations.

comment.narrative:
1. Key infrastructure destroyed in the intensified conflict since mid-2014 disrupting the regular functioning of hospitals, schools, roads, electricity networks, power grids, and police stations. 2. Limited capacities of the local authorities to ensure socioeconomic recovery and deliver services, including for the most vulnerable. 3. Weak and fragmented RoL institutions with low capacities and untrained staff. 5. No opportunities for SMEs or advancing economic literacy for the most vulnerable population. 6. Limited to lack of access to funding for the most vulnerable population. 7.Lack of viable economic opportunities for jobs and income generation for youth, including vulnerable groups (IDPs, returnees, and migrants).
a) Only 2 out of 10 municipalities used participatory planning process (UNDP Rapid Diagnostic, 2015). b) N/A c) N/A d) No municipalities using gender-specific indicators or tools in policy-making (UNDP Rapid Diagnostic, 2015).

title.narrative: Advancing Libyan Womens Participation During the Transi

description.narrative: The project will support participation of Libyan women in decision-making during the political transition phase, supporting integrated of women's rights in the transitional processes, policies and legislation.

title.narrative: Amendment to the Project Document Feb 2017
Advance Women Participation in the Political Transition
Event Management Services in Cities (Benghazi, Albaida and Tobruk)
Event Management Services in Cities (Tripoli, and Temenhent)
INTERNATIONAL CONSULTANT ? MEDIA AND COMMUNICATION CONSULTANT FOR THE PEACE CAMPAIGN
RFQ/LBY/AML/2017/039 : Design, Production and Supply of visibility items for the Peace Campaign
Advancement of participation of Libyan women project

description.narrative: Output 1: Gender mainstreaming and integration of women's rights in transitional institutions strengthened. Output 2: Participation of Libyan women in the transition process enhanced.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The project will support the advancement of participation of Libyan women in decision making during the political transition phase.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

comment.narrative: Article 12 in the Political Agreement Stipulates the establishment of the Womens Support and Empowerment Unit in the Presidential Council. The CEDAW of Libya has been ratified. Womens Agenda for Peace developed by a group of key Libyan women with the support of UNSMIL. Advocacy and Pressure Group on the Presidency Council established and has eight members. No jointly agreed approach by the international community on gender engagement in Libya.
1. HOR conference for women parliamentarians 2. Pressure group meeting

A consultative meeting was held on 21-23 October 2016, with the Advocacy and Lobby group (LWAF). The meeting aimed to assist the group to continue their advocacy work on womens political participation. the outcome of the consultative meeting was as follows: New name for the group as Libyan Women Advocacy Forces (LWF). Developed LWAF mandate, identify, objectives and vision. Developed slogan and log for the LWAF. Develop a mini-communication strategy. Developed coordination strategy for the group Developed a code of conduct. Developed internal conflict resolutions mechanism for the group. Furthermore LWAF met on with Ms. Margot Wallstrom, the minister of Foreign Affairs, Sweden. LWAF presented the priorities of Libyan women as well as discussed concrete Swedish support to Libyan women initiatives, in light of the possible Swedish 2016-2020 MENA strategy. A Libyan Parliamentarian Women three days conference organized towards effective role in the House of Representatives. Women parliamentarians from neighbouring countries such as Tunis, Algeria, Egypt, Sudan, Chad and Niger would were also invited. At the end result of the conference: Confidence and solidarity among Libyan female members of the HoRs enhanced; Female members of the HoRs are informed of ways to be effective in their functions; Female members of HoRs created network with female members from the neighboring countries; Female members of the HoRs build consensus around issues pertaining working together for one common goal.

Output 1: Women's caucus established within key institutions. At least one law approved in favor of women. At least 100 men decision makers from key institutions trained on women's rights. National gender strategy and National Action Plan of UNSCR 1325 developed by the end of the project.
Output 2: Women's organizations from all regions participate in the peace co-existence campaign. Campaign on peace co-existence launched all over Libya. Youth and community based organizations join the campaign.

1.1. Female member of the House of Representatives trained on how to develop strategies, legislation and action plan so as to establish Womens Caucus in the Parliament
1.2. Libyan Womens Forum for Constitution and Laws was established and revised all Libyan laws and the constitution from a gender perspective, and made recommendations to amend the existing laws and to enact new laws that promote and protect womens rights.
1.3. (23) men from the House of the Representatives and Higher National Council of Election trained on Gender Sensitive Budgeting.
1.4. Civil Society Organizations were supported to engage with the UN senior leadership in the UN Women Peace and Security Open Day.
1.5. (70) Libyan Women attended Libyan Womens Peace Follow UP Conference that resulted in the development of Peace Campaign Plan to be launched in 8 cities in Libya.
2.1. Peace Campaign Design and Planning meetings were held for a group of Civil Society Organizations that resulted in the development of Peace Libya Campaign to be launched in 8 cities in Libya.
2.2. Seven (7) Focal Points trained on culture of peace and reconciliation so as to company and launch Peace Campaign in 8 cities in Libya
2.3. Seven (7) Steering Committees were established in four locations in Libya so as to company and launch Peace Campaign in Libya

description.narrative: The project will promote an inclusive vision for national reconciliation by supporting development of a national reconciliation strategy as well as strengthening bottom-up local reconciliation initiatives.

title.narrative: National Media and Outreach Campaign on National Reconciliation in Libya
RFP - Baseline Perception Survey for the National Reconciliation Project in Libya

description.narrative: Output 1: National reconciliation strategy developed through a consultative and inclusive process. Output 2: Bottom-up reconciliation processes strengthened and relevant civil society actors, in particular youth, capacitated.
capital of a political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

1. a. Percent of participant stakeholders who rate the consultations as useful. 1. b. Percent of participant stakeholders who rate the consultations as inclusive. 1. c. Percent of Libyans surveyed who view the national reconciliation process as fair and transparent. 1. d. Percent of Libyans surveyed who approve of the national reconciliation strategy. 1.1.1. Progress towards adoption of national strategy for reconciliation (scale from 0 to 5): 1. Technical advisory committee is established; 2. Roadmap is agreed; 3. Consultations (thematic, geographic, and with youth and women) take place; 4. Draft strategy is finalized with inputs from all stakeholders; 5. National strategy is approved. 1.1.2. Number of qualitative interactions between national and local level reconciliation actors. 1.2.1. Progress towards completion of study on perceptions and understandings of reconciliation and social cohesion. (scale 0 to 5): 0. No activities started; 1. TORs of study developed; 2. RFP published; 3. Contractor selected; 4. Survey conducted; 5. First report published. 1.2.2. Number of social media activists, bloggers and media actors trained on conducting outreach and awareness campaigns on reconciliation. 1.2.3. Number of media activities supported on the topic reconciliation. 1.2.4. Number of people reached through media campaign: a. estimated population reached through documentaries. b. estimated population reached through TV spots. c. weekly number of social media impressions generated in Facebook and Twitter. d. estimated audience reached via TV/radio shows. 1.3.1. Number of identified stakeholders capacitated to engage in issues of mediation, dialogue, restorative justice, gender, as well as collaborative leadership. 1.3.2. Number of people successfully trained as local facilitators and mediators. 1.3.3. Number of research papers developed on reconciliation mechanisms and initiatives. 2. a. Percent of Libyans surveyed who have a positive impression of the o

comment.narrative: No reconciliation strategy exists and no consultations have taken place. No outreach and awareness campaign exists. Bottom-up initiatives are few and uncoordinated. Perception survey of Libyan citizens on attitudes towards reconciliation has not taken place. No studies capturing Libyan citizens views and mechanisms in use for reconciliation.

Technical advisory committee is established and operational. A roadmap for the elaboration of the national strategy has been agreed. 5 thematic, 6 regional and 2 youth and women consultation meetings. Perception study on Libyan attitudes towards reconciliation has taken place and first report published. 2 trainings of social media actors have taken place. Production of 2 documentaries, 4 media spots and 5 radio shows on reconciliation has been supported. Awareness campaign has been launched. 2 stakeholder trainings have been conducted. 2 meetings of local facilitators supported. Analysis of traditional reconciliation mechanisms finalized and report published. 2 micro-capital grant contracts awarded to CSOs working in reconciliation. 3 meetings with local reconciliation actors held. 1 micro-capital grant contract awarded to awareness campaign NGO partner. 2 youth dialogues held.
To be completed early 2018

description.narrative: The project seeks to promote an inclusive constitution-making process through participation of Libyan civil society organizations, NGOs, active citizens including women and youth, decision-makers, parliamentarians and the Constitution Drafting Assembly.

Output 1: Ability of the Constitution Drafting Assembly to outreach enhanced. Output 2: General population knowledge on the new constitution enhanced. Output 3: Civil society engagement in the constitution-making process strengthened.
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

The adoption and implementation of a consultative and public outreach process by the CDA, and the ability of CSOs to access the CDA. Media/communication strategy for CDA put in place
Activities implemented based on academic contributions, and the targeted population through media messages on constitutional process.
Translation of draft constitutional documentation into all proposed national languages for Libya. - Number of candidates to the CDA trained in media.
The engagement of CSO's supported by the UNDP in the Libyan constitution-making process. The capacity development of different Libyan components and categories's and CSOs to discuss the daft constitution.
The number of small MCGs awarded through competitive and transparent process to organize outreach campaign

comment.narrative:
The CDA in place with very low communication and outreach capacities.
1 constitutional survey carried out. 17 constitutional debates organised.
Constitutional Dialogues organised by a CSO across the country. Facilitators for constitutional dialogues trained. Funding mechanism for CSO grantees working on constitution launched.

The CDA has been provided with the means to implement public consultation and outreach process for receiving public consultations.
Media/communication strategy for the CDA put in place, the CDA to be provided with assistance in media and communication.
Libyan population receive informed messages on the constitution making process and substance, and population engaged in the constitution-making through participation in targeted survey
Libyan academia and other key stakeholders have been engaged in the constitution-making process through the production of papers, organization of public debates and workshops.
Enhanced coordination between Libyan and international actors in the constitution-making process.
CSOs/NGOs are equipped with the necessary tools, instruments and capacity to effectively engage media and outreach campaign

Communications conducted for CDA media presence Follow up with some CSos
The project moved the remaining indicator to the AWP 2017

O1 Number of studies, periodicals, legal texts in Arabic language disseminated to the CDA. Media/communication strategy for CDA put in place - No. of CDA outreach activities implemented - Ability of CSOs to access the CDA - No. of the CDA members benefiting from technical workshop
O2 Number of workshops based on academic contributions Number of population targeted by media messages on constitutional process and substance Translation of draft constitutional documentation into all proposed national languages for Libya Number of persons receiving draft legal documents
03 Number of CSOs supported by UNDP to foster their engagement and inclusion in the Libyan constitution-making process,
to be reported when project closure is ready by early 2018

title.narrative: UNSMIL/UNDP Policing and Security Joint Programme

description.narrative: This project seeks to support the Libyan government effort towards effective police operations and services reintegrated into host communities and to improve public confidence to provide security and justice services.
Structure, roles and resourcing of local police and criminal justice institutions clarified and prioritised according to identified needs in Tripoli
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The project will be implemented in Tripoli

description.narrative: Indicator 1: Criminal justice and law enforcement institutions in Tripoli have clear and updated organisational structures in place. Indicator 2: De facto cooperation exists between judicial police and MOI/police to address security needs in Tripoli Indicator 3: Indicator 4:

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: None baseline 2: None Baseline 3: Baseline 4:

target 1: Criminal justice and law enforcement institutions in Tripoli have clear and updated organisational structures in place. Target 2: De facto cooperation exists between judicial police and MOI/police to address security needs in Tripoli target 3: option target 4:

Prodoc signed in September 2017. Tracking of indicators to begin in early 2018. Following activities started in January 2017:
Core government functions assessment on policing and security completed was conducted for debriefing the UNSMIL and the donor community. Agreement between UNSMIL and UNDP Libya on the project scope of work decided under the Global Focal Point Arrangements . Concept note and PRODOC being devised.
Technical adviser hired in late March 2017 to support concept note and project document development in Q2/Q3. Libyan government invited in April to brief UNDP on specific needs to be address by the project and subsequently to provide feedback on the fist draft of the project concept note. Two Global Focal Point missions were deployed to Libya facilitated by the Technical Adviser for further analyse the concept note and to facilitate the Joint Programme arrangement between UNSMIL and UNDP. During this quarter the Tripoli Security Plan was signed by the Libyan Government and UNSMIL which enabled project planning to proceed.
Project manager sourced and hired in August 2017. Stakeholder engagement with MOI and police initiated in August 2017. First donor funding agreement (INL State Department, $1.95m) secured. Donation of $1m funding from UNDP BPPS secured. Project document and budget finalised by project manager and technical adviser. Project document signed jointly by UNDP Libya, UNSMIL, and Libyan Ministry of Interior on 21 September 2017.
Technical level focal points identified jointly by MOI and UNDP, and engaged over October and November to devise project mplementation plan. Discussions on implementation plan held with stakeholders in other line ministries (Ministry of Justice, Ministry of Planning). Annual Work Plan 2018 devised. Terms of reference for project board negotiated with board members. First donor consortium meeting held. First project board meeting held. Risk assessment and mitigation strategy devised for implementation in Annu

Support HNEC in the planning, preparation and conduct of national and local elections and out of country voting. Develop HNEC institutional and staff capacities and raise awareness on the requirements of electoral processes that are transparent, credible and promote inclusive participation. promote public participation in electoral processes, targeting vulnerable groups with activities that enable them to exercise their right to vote. Raising the electoral awareness of local partners, enabling them to perform their role effectively in the electoral process and contribute to a peaceful electoral environment.
